awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: EAGER-QIA: High-Genus Code-Based Cryptography
awd_abstract_narration:
Cryptography protects confidential communications: electronic commerce, voter information, diplomatic communication, human-rights interviews, medical records, and much more. However, attackers recording messages today will be able to decrypt those messages with future quantum computers. The most confidence-inspiring response is the McEliece cryptosystem, which has a strong security track record and is a leading contender for standardization of post-quantum cryptography, but this cryptosystem has a key size around a megabyte. Applications that cannot afford megabyte keys are currently forced to use cryptosystems whose security is much less stable. This project aims to build new post-quantum systems that bring McEliece's security stability and confidence to a wider range of applications.

The public key in McEliece's cryptosystem is a generator matrix for a subfield subcode of an error-correcting code, specifically a genus-0 Goppa code. Subfield subcodes of higher-genus Goppa codes can correct more errors for the same code length and code dimension, improving the tradeoffs between efficiency and security. Showing that cryptosystems built from these codes can run at reasonable speed will require vertically integrated optimization of cryptosystem design, curve selection, decoding algorithms, algorithms for computer algebra, and vectorized software, with the further challenges of ensuring security against both mathematical and microarchitectural attacks.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Most user data sent through the Internet today is encrypted with 2048-bit RSA or 256-bit ECC. The encrypted data is being recorded by attackers, and the encryption will be broken by quantum computers running Shor's algorithm.

Post-quantum cryptography is designed to resist quantum computers. However, many post-quantum cryptosystems have been broken. To minimize risks, applications prioritizing security use the McEliece cryptosystem (https://mceliece.org), which was introduced in 1978 and has the strongest track record of all proposals for public-key encryption.

This project's top outcomes, with various coauthors, are as follows. This project introduced CryptAttackTester (https://cat.cr.yp.to), a framework for high-assurance analyses of attack performance; used CryptAttackTester to precisely quantify the performance of McEliece attacks and, for comparison, the performance of AES attacks; formally verified proofs of theorems regarding McEliece decryption; sped up software for users of the McEliece cryptosystem; released a software library (https://lib.mceliece.org) for developers to integrate the McEliece cryptosystem into applications; and introduced Jacobian Goppa codes, which enable a new version of the McEliece cryptosystem for future applications that want smaller public keys but all the same reasons for security confidence. As a side result, for applications that instead use the CRS/CSIDH line of isogeny-based cryptosystems, this project obtained a 2x speedup in those cryptosystems, setting a new performance baseline for isogeny-based cryptography.
